beat.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to get the most points, votes etc in a game, race, or competition
beat somebody hollow British English,  beat the pants off somebody American English (=defeat them easily)
beat.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Labour easily beat the Conservatives in the last election.
I beat him more often at pool than he beats me.
beat.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to hit someone or something many times with your hand, a stick etc
beat the living daylights out of somebody (=beat someone very hard)
beat.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: photographs of rioters beating a policeman
The woman had been beaten to death by her husband.
beat.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to hit against something many times or continuously
beat.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Sid beat on the door with his hand.
beat.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to do something better, faster etc than what was best before
beat.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The company’s profits are unlikely to beat last year’s £10 million.
The record set by Kierson in '84 has yet to be beaten.
beat.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to be much better and more enjoyable than something else
beat.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Fresh milk beats powdered milk any time.
You can’t beat swimming as a good all-body exercise.
For excitement, you just can’t beat college basketball.
‘Well, ’ said Culley, ‘it beats going to the office.’
beat.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to mix things together quickly with a fork or special kitchen machine
beat.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Beat the eggs, then add the milk.
Beat the butter and sugar together until fluffy.
beat.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to successfully deal with a problem that you have been struggling with
beat.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: advice on how to beat depression
the government’s long fight to beat inflation
beat.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: when your heart beats, it moves in a regular rhythm as it pumps your blood
beat.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The average person’s heart beats 70 times a minute.
beat.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if you beat drums, or if drums beat, they make a regular continuous sound
beat.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if a bird beats its wings, or if its wings beat, they move up and down quickly and regularly
beat.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to avoid situations in which a lot of people are trying to do something, usually by doing something early
beat.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: We left at four a.m. to beat the traffic.
Shopping by mail order lets you beat the queues.
Shop now and beat the Christmas rush!
beat.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to get or do something before someone else, especially if you are both trying to do it first
beat.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: I wanted the last piece of pie, but somebody beat me to it.
They wanted to make it into a film, but another studio beat them to the punch.
John had beaten me to the breakfast table.
beat.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to hit metal with a hammer in order to shape it or make it thinner
beat.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to force wild birds and animals out of bushes, long grass etc so that they can be shot for sport
beat.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: Jason easily beats me at chess every time we play.
New Zealand narrowly beat the Springboks in South Africa.
He comfortably beat the second placed candidate.
In each event she soundly beat her opponents.
He should be able to beat them all hands down.
There’s no point trying to offer excuses as to why we were so comprehensively beaten.
beat somebody into second/third etc place
He was beaten into second place in the Monaco Grand Prix.
beat.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: to get more points, votes etc than someone. Beat  is used especially in spoken English
We should have beaten them easily.
I always beat my brother at tennis.
to beat someone. Defeat is more formal than beat and is used especially in writing
England were defeated by 2 goals to 1.
Bush defeated Kerry in the election.
to defeat someone completely in a game
to beat someone very easily in a game
Of course, they totally creamed the other team.
to beat someone completely in a game or argument
She wiped the floor with her opponent in the debate.
They won a £1,000 prize after wiping the floor with the opposition in a bowling competition.
beat.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: one of a series of regular movements or hitting actions
beat.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: a heart rate of 80 beats a minute
the steady beat of the drum
beat.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: the main rhythm that a piece of music or a poem has
beat.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: a song with a beat you can dance to
beat.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a subject or area of a city that someone is responsible for as their job
beat.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: People like to see police officers on the beat.
beat.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: one of the notes in a piece of music that sounds stronger than the other notes
beat.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Come and sit down – you must be dead beat.
